simulation_equations: EW_HeII = f(Mdot, beta, Vinf, R, T)

constants_required.name: x_WLR
constants_required.description: Slope of the wind momentum-luminosity relationship

constants_required.name: D_WLR
constants_required.value_or_range: function of Z, approximately 0.6 * log(Z/Z_solar) for low metallicity

constants_required.name: T_eff
constants_required.description: Effective temperature for O6.5 III star

constants_required.name: Vinf_base
constants_required.value_or_range: 1500 km/s (typical for O-type stars at low metallicity)

variables_to_vary.name: beta
variables_to_vary.description: Exponent of the wind velocity law

variables_to_vary.name: Mdot
variables_to_vary.description: Mass-loss rate adjusted to maintain constant Q-parameter
variables_to_vary.range: computed from Q constraint for each beta

procedure_steps: Step 1: Initialize constants (sigma, c, L_solar, R_solar, M_solar, T_eff, R_star, Vinf_base, Z) and convert units to SI where necessary
Step 2: Calculate stellar luminosity L using L = 4 * pi * sigma * R_star^2 * T_eff^4
Step 3: For each Q_target value in the range, create a parameter sweep loop
Step 4: For each beta value in [0.8, 1.0, 1.2, 1.4, 1.6, 1.8, 2.0], calculate the required Mdot using Mdot = Q_target * Vinf_base * R_star^1.5
Step 5: Calculate the modified wind momentum Dmom = Mdot * Vinf_base * sqrt(R_star)
Step 6: Verify WLR consistency by computing log(Dmom / (L/c)) and comparing with x_WLR * log(L/L_solar) + D_WLR(Z)
Step 7: Model the wind velocity profile v(r) = Vinf_base * (1 - R_star/r)^beta for radial distances r from 1.0*R_star to 10.0*R_star

Step 8: Calculate a proxy for He II 4686 emission line equivalent width using EW_HeII_proxy = integral over wind of emission function proportional to (Mdot * rho(r)^2 * ionization_fraction(r)) where rho(r) scales with Mdot/(4*pi*r^2*v(r))

Step 9: For simplified emission calculation, use EW_HeII_proxy = k * Mdot^alpha * beta^gamma where k is normalization constant, alpha ~ 1.5-2.0 (emission scales superlinearly with density), gamma ~ -0.5 to -1.0 (higher beta reduces inner wind density and emission)
Step 10: Store results for each (beta, Q_target) combination: beta, Mdot, Dmom, WLR_deviation, EW_HeII_proxy
Step 11: Generate visualizations: (a) EW_HeII_proxy vs beta for each Q_target, (b) Mdot vs beta for each Q_target, (c) WLR deviation vs beta, (d) wind velocity profiles v(r) for different beta values
Step 12: Calculate percentage change in EW_HeII_proxy between beta=0.8 and beta=2.0 to quantify the measurable decrease predicted by the hypothesis
expected_outcomes: The simulation should reveal: (1) A measurable decrease in He II 4686 emission line equivalent width (EW_HeII_proxy) as beta increases from 0.8 to 2.0, with the decrease being approximately 20-50% based on the slower inner wind acceleration reducing emission region density; (2) Mass-loss rate Mdot increases proportionally with beta to maintain constant Q-parameter, demonstrating the interdependence between Mdot and beta; (3) The modified wind momentum Dmom remains consistent with the wind momentum-luminosity relationship across all beta values, with deviations less than 0.1-0.2 dex, confirming that the WLR is maintained despite varying beta; (4) Wind velocity profiles show progressively slower acceleration in the inner wind (r < 3R_star) as beta increases, with higher beta values producing more extended acceleration zones; (5) The relationship holds across different Q_target values, indicating robustness of the beta-EW relationship in low-metallicity environments (Z < 0.2 Z_solar); (6) The results should demonstrate that high beta values (approaching 2.0) are physically consistent with observed stellar wind properties and WLR constraints, supporting the hypothesis that this may be a general property of low-metallicity O-type stellar winds rather than unique to GHV-62024
